review.title: A Hybrid Approach to Word Sense Disambiguation Combining Supervised and Unsupervised Learning
review.abstract: In this paper, we are going to find meaning of words based on distinct situations. Word Sense Disambiguation is used to find meaning of words based on live contexts using supervised and unsupervised approaches. Unsupervised approaches use online dictionary for learning, and supervised approaches use manual learning sets. Hand tagged data are populated which might not be effective and sufficient for learning procedure. This limitation of information is main flaw of the supervised approach. Our proposed approach focuses to overcome the limitation using learning set which is enriched in dynamic way maintaining new data. Trivial filtering method is utilized to achieve appropriate training data. We introduce a mixed methodology having Modified Lesk approach and Bag-of-Words having enriched bags using learning methods. Our approach establishes the superiority over individual Modified Lesk and Bag-of-Words approaches based on experimentation.

Word Sense Disambiguation is used to find the meaning of words based on live contexts, using monitored and unmonitored approaches. Unmonitored approaches use online dictionaries for learning, and monitored approaches use manual learning sets. Hand-marked data is filled with data that may not be effective and sufficient for learning processes. This information limitation is the main flaw of the monitored approach. Our proposed approach focuses on overcoming the limitation by means of learning sets, which are dynamically enriched with new data. Trivial filtering methods are used to obtain appropriate training data. We will introduce a mixed methodology with "Modified Read" approach and "Bag-of-Words" approaches that are enriched with learning methods Word-based on the individual approach to Bathing-based learning.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: In human languages around the world, there are a lot of words with different meanings depending on the context. Word Sense Disambiguation (WSD) [1-5] is the process of identifying the likely meaning of ambiguous words based on different situations. The word "bank" has several meanings, such as "place for supervising transactions," "turning point of a flow," and so on. Such words with ambiguous meanings are inherently ambiguous. The process of identification to determine the appropriate meaning of an ambiguous word for a particular context is known as WSD. Humans decide the meaning of a word based on the characteristic points of a discussion or situation with their own merits. Machines have no ability to decide such an ambiguous situation unless some protocols have been planted in the machines.

sections.heading: 2. RELATED WORK
sections.text: Many algorithms have been developed in WSD on the basis of supervised and unsupervised learning. "Reading" and "Bag-of-Words" are two well-known methods discussed in this section as the basis of our proposed approach.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preliminaries of Bag-of-Words
sections.text: The Bag of Words approach is a model used in Natural Language Processing (NLP) to determine the actual meaning of a word with different meanings based on different contexts. In this approach, there is a pocket for each meaning of a keyword (unique word) and all pockets are filled manually. If the meaning of a keyword were unique, the sentence (containing the keyword) is picked up and the entire sentence broken down into individual words. Then, every word in the sentence (except "stop words") would be compared with every word of any "sense pocket" that searches for the maximum frequency of common words.

sections.heading: 5. EXPERIMENTAL RESULT
sections.text: Typical literal disambiguation approaches examine efficiency on the basis of three parameters such as "precision," "recall," and "F-measure." [20] Precision (P) is the ratio of "matched target words based on human choice" and "number of instances the system responds to the respective words." The callback value (R) is the ratio of "number of target words for which the response matches the human response" and "total number of target words in the data set." F-measure is evaluated as "(2 * P * R / (P + R)," based on the calculation of precision and recall value. CONCLUSIONS In this paper, our approach has established better performance in the improved WSD technique depending on specific learning sets. Accuracy of disambiguity is improved as data sets are populated with new data. We have achieved better precision values, memory values and F-Measures through extensive experiments.
